The fallacy here is called bait and switch, also known as the strawman. The basic technique is to try to refute idea X by looking at idea Y and refuting it and then claiming that you’ve refuted X when in fact you didn’t discuss it. The problem with this article is that it repeats the usual ignorant American right wing canard of referring to aspects of the type of economy that existed in the Soviet Union, and then say, “This shows socialism can’t work.” To quote the cited article: “Under socialism, incentives either play a minimal role or are ignored totally. A centrally planned economy without market prices or profits, where property is owned by the state, is a system without an effective incentive mechanism to direct economic activity.” This makes two mistakes. First, socialism is not an economy “where property is owned by the state”. And, second, it need not be a “centrally planned economy”. The article basically poses a false dichotomy: “Either a capitalist economy with market and prices” or a state run centrally planned economy. That’s a fallacy of false dichotomy because those aren’t the only two possibilities. Socialism is a contested concept so I will here point out the way that many revolutionary socialists — especially libertarian socialists — view it. On our view socialism is about the liberation of workers from being a subordinate, exploited class, a class forced to seek jobs under autocratic workplace regimes — as under capitalism. So this means a necessary condition of an authentic socialist economy is collective, democratic worker self-management of the industries. That is inconsistent with state ownership and control of the economy. A state is based on corporate-style managerialist hierarchies where the workers are subordinate and must “do as you’re told.” That is a regime of class oppression, not socialism. Second, the system of social production, to be socialist, must be directly accountable to the masses of people in terms of its effects on them — what it produces, what environmental effects it has. Capitalism fails on this score since firms engage in systemic cost shifting — pollution being the most obvious example. But direct social accountability of the production system to the masses is inconsistent with some top down system of statist central planning. Rather the old bureaucrtic-military-police state would need to be broken down and governance re-organized on a more directly democratic way for authentic socialism to exist. The cited article is also mistaken when it suggests a capitalist economy is based on “incentives.” The “incentive” for the working class to submit to the autocratic managerialist regime is: “You better do what we want or we’ll let you starve.” That’s the capitalist meaning of “incentives”.

This is a statement masked as a question: you state that socialism “always fails” without qualifying it and providing criterion for evaluating “failure”. You also fail to describe what you mean by “socialism”, which is crucial because there are different models of socialism that differ drastically in their institutional design. This lack of qualification essentially renders your question meaningless. Nevertheless I will humor you by providing examples of socialist elements that exist in today’s world which lend credence to the viability of a socialist system. Publicly-owned enterprise: There are highly efficient state-owned enterprises in the economies of Norway, Singapore, formerly in France (before they were privatized) and increasingly in the People’s Republic of China following years of reform. Furthermore, Alaska pays each of its citizens an annual social dividend derived from the public ownership of its natural resources, and Norway’s sovereign wealth fund is used to finance its pension fund. In Singapore’s case, revenue from its government-linked companies is increasingly used to finance social spending.Cooperatives: There are plenty of examples of highly efficient employee-owned cooperatives, the most notable being the Mondragon Cooperative Corporation in Spain. These enterprises are owned by their workers collectively, and some like Mondragon are democratically-managed.Self-management: Many firms are embracing greater flexibility and employee self-management in their organization and recognizing that strictly hierarchical forms of management are becoming increasingly ineffective in a modern knowledge-driven information economy. This is most prevalent in the most innovative sectors of the economy like technology and software development.Open-source software: This is more than just socialistic and is essentially communistic because the concept of ownership is negated by sharing of source code, with everyone contributing voluntarily based on their own abilities and freely taking the output according to their own needs without any need for money, rationing, or compelled labor.While none of these examples constitute socialism by themselves, they do represent examples of “working” - and by that I mean effective and efficient - processes that could easily be combined to constitute a basic market socialist economy. Thus far political will has prevented such a formation from being implemented. With respect to the more comprehensive notion of socialism as a system that dispenses with the dynamic of the accumulation of capital and the profit system, socialism has not yet existed as the technical preconditions for its emergence have yet to be realized. The feasibility of non-market socialism requires a level of technology which enables real-time inventory management of intermediate inputs on an economy-wide scale and the ability to transmit supply and demand information throughout an economy-wide network at a lower transaction cost than the factor market process of capitalism. Political will is not sufficient for such a system to emerge; socialism is only made possible by advances in technology that make new, non-market forms of resource allocation both feasible and more efficient than extant capitalistic processes. While such a system might be on the verge of technical feasibility, the existing elite and ruling classes are loath to explore any post-capitalist system because such a system eliminates their roles and privileged positions. Political will alone cannot achieve socialism, and the mere fact that a ruling political party has “socialist” in its title doesn’t make a country’s economy socialist. As an example, if a socialist president were elected in the United States, that fact alone would do nothing to alter the actual processes of the American economy and automatically transform the United States into a socialist economy. Countries like the former Soviet Union and the contemporary People’s Republic of China are at most “socialist states” - countries whose official goal is the realization of socialism. Whether or not their respective means of achieving socialism are effective in working toward that goal is an entirely different question altogether; the key point is that disagreeing with their means of achieving socialism or their practical day-to-day policies is entirely different from disagreeing with the goal of having a socialist economy and the desirability of socialism. It is also important to note that the socialist political movement, or socialist state, or a particular socialist party and its actions is not definition of socialism. Socialism is defined as a distinct socioeconomic system.

You would think that building something like a road, that is financed collectively, and publicly available for free should be possible. And yet humans have been trying for thousands of years, and not a single meter of road could ever be built. Somehow, there is something about governments that just makes them utterly incompetent, no matter what kind of government we are talking about. They pay builders, and follow the correct engineering methods, and try to build roads, and then it just doesn’t work, because socialism.  Obviously the result of socialism It’s a really weird thing to see! There is even a famous scientific experiment about it: Shroedinger’s road. The idea is that you take a construction company, and task them with building a road. And the funding has a 50% chance of being public, and 50% chance of being private. And when the road is finished, it exists in a superposition of working and not working. If you look at the source of the funding, it collapses the wave structure, and the road either works because it was private funding, or doesn't work if it was public funding. The mere act of observation can change reality, isn’t physics interesting? The fundamental law of nature that “socialism doesn’t work” is first credited to Adam Smith, who also invented the idea of trading stuff in 1776.  Sarcasm aside, honestly, it’s weird to me when people claim that it’s completely impossible for public infrastructure or services to exist, and that it always fails.

Short answer The premise of the question is wrong. Indeed the premise of the question is almost as wrong as it is possible for a statement to be. The answer to “where in the world has socialism ever worked?” is “everywhere that there were human beings, for the vast majority of the time that there were human beings”. Long answer For the vast majority of the time that human beings have existed, the statements “This is my land—you can’t go on it unless I give permission” and even “This is my food—I don’t have to share it if I don’t want to” would have seemed obviously wrong, indeed probably insane, and certainly dangerous. Human survival required that land be held in common, and that the product of one’s labor be shared. If you had to give this system a name from modern politics, what would you give it? Surely ‘communism’—or perhaps ‘anarchism’, since there was nothing resembling a state (the idea we have of ‘cavemen’ having tribal chieftains or councils of elders is false). But this would, I imagine, come within your definition of ‘socialism’. So human beings were universally ‘socialists’ for the vast majority of the time that they have existed. What happened when they abandoned ‘socialism’? http://www3.gettysburg.edu/~dperry/Class%20Readings%20Scanned%20Documents/Intro/Diamond.PDF ‘The worst mistake in the history of the human race’ according to (in this case) Guns, Germs and Steel author Jared Diamond. The beginning of slavery, despotism, and (by some definitions of the word) war. So human beings were universally socialist for the vast majority of the time that they existed, and the abandonment of socialism was a catastrophe. ‘Non-socialism’, this strange system that we have been trying to make work recently, is so impractical that we call a society long-lived and stable if it lasts for a few thousand years, not the minimum of 50,000 years (it depends what you count as a ‘human being’) that ‘socialism’ lasted. The premise of the question is not just wrong, but is almost the opposite of the truth.

It’s a good question but a bit naive as well. One has to realize that transitioning from one social formation to another isn’t easy and fails many times before succeeding. That is actually the history of capitalism and it’s long and bloody transition from feudalism. So why did Socialism fail in the twentieth century? My opinion is that there really never was socialism yet anywhere. For instance, in the Soviet Union you really had a state capitalist bureaucracy with social programs. This was recognized as such even by people like Stalin despite the west calling it socialism or communism. How to have a successful socialist society would be to eliminate any fundamental processes or accepts of capitalism. Otherwise, whatever you start with will eventually become capitalism. Also, you need a clearly enough worked out socialist alternative to capitalism which has not happened yet. The left does not have a complete theory of that so it spends most of it’s time criticizing capitalism and trying to make it less harsh.

Debatable, but historians and analysts cite one example of a socialist society that more or less worked: The Kibbutz communities of Israel. I’ll leave the googling and the final verdict to you, but the Kibbutz experience of Israel is often cited as a success story in implemented socialism. To cite a few features: Living in the Kibbutz was reportedly voluntary; no one was forced to live there.The Socialist doctrine of “to each according to his need and from each according to his abilities” was practiced there.There was no private ownership in the Kibbutz.Even children were raised by the community as a whole, not in individual families.The Kibbutzim were productive AF!As I said, citing the Kibbutz as an example of successful socialism might draw debate from all over the place. I’d suggest you do your own research and form your own verdict about it.

Generally speaking, the most successful economies have a mix of both. England, Norway, Germany, and Japan all have some form of socialized medicine, and socialized transportation, and compete quite well otherwise. The United States has corporate medical care, and it is so expensive that it is literally making it harder for U.S. corporations to compete. One of the reasons that car companies have trouble keeping their US plants profitable is that corporate health insurance raises the price of the car more than value-added tax would.
